text: Green Smoothie
Next up is the green smoothie. I love
this dish because it's like a summertime
palette cleanser.
It's loaded with healthy ingredients and
tastes absolutely delicious. You might
have heard that you shouldn't consume
fruit in juice form because it strips
away all the fiber and lets your body
absorb sugar unnaturally fast. This is
all true, but it doesn't apply to
smoothies. The key difference is that
for smoothies, you don't remove the
solid parts of the fruits and
vegetables. You just blend them all
together. This means you still get their
natural fiber content, which regulates
sugar absorption, feeds your gut
microbiota, and prevents inflammation.
In fact, adding vegetables, nuts, and
fats to your smoothie dilutes the sugar
content of the fruit, slowing down
absorption even more and keeping you
full for longer. All right, let's get
going. First, add in your macadamia nut.
Adding the liquid first stops your
ingredients from stalling the blender.
Next, add in one banana, frozen if
possible, to thicken the consistency of
the smoothie. Then add in the rest of
your ingredients. Mac nuts, three frozen
cherries,
pomegranate seeds,
hemp seeds,
wheat grass,
vanilla extract,
chia seeds,
juice of half of a lemon, and one celery
stock. These were all chosen for a
reason. Pomegranates have unique
polyphenols that protects your
cholesterol from oxidation, which all
improves your blood flow. Dark cherries
have another distinct type of elite
polyphenols that help with
cardiovascular health and are rich in
melatonin, which helps with sleep. Hemp
seeds are a great source of essential
omega-3 and omega6 fat with a remarkable
32% protein content. Close the lid and
give everything a good blend for 30
seconds.
Next, add in a handful or two of washed
spinach and blend again until all your
ingredients are thoroughly mixed. Take
your glass and serve your smoothie. Note
that this will be a thicker smoothie. If
you want to make it less thick, you can
always add in more filtered water or
your choice of nutmilk. Top off with a
little strawberry and mint and you're
ready to go. This is a great meal prep
smoothie. You can make a big batch and
store in the fridge in an airtight
container for up to 3 to 4 days. Just
make sure to give it a quick stir or

timestamp: Finally, we have the roasted vegetable,
chickpea, and lentil bowl. I love this
dish because I have learned to
absolutely love vegetables and legumes.
Roasting makes the vegetables sweet and
juicy. The lentils are packed with
protein, and the creamy chickpea
dressing has a great hit of high
polyphenol olive oil. Of our three
recipes, this might be the most
satisfying to eat.
Preheat your oven to 400° and start
chopping the vegetables. We'll start
with half of a cauliflower and cut into
bite-sized pieces. Keep the other half
in your fridge for later, or you can
double the recipe to make more portions.
Set this aside in a mixing bowl and chop
up one zucchini.
Now, take your red bell pepper, cut the
top and bottom like this. Cut in the
middle and slice out the bitter white
membrane before chopping into bite-sized
pieces.
Once you're done chopping vegetables,
measure about 1 teaspoon of macadamia
nut oil or any kind of oil with a high
smoke point like avocado. Take a tiny
bit of this oil and spread onto your
baking sheet to prevent sticking when
the vegetables are in the oven. Then add
the rest of your oil to your bowl of
mixed vegetables. Give everything a good
toss and add to your baking sheet.
Spread evenly and place in the oven at
400° for about 15 minutes. Now that the
vegetables are in the oven, we'll start
cooking our black lentils. Lentils are
18% protein, but also 16% fiber, which
again slows down food absorption, making
you fuller for longer and reducing blood
sugar spikes.
Studies suggest that eating 10 g of
legume fibers every day lowers colon
cancer risk by 32% versus just 10% for
the same amount of other dietary fibers.
Add about 1 and 1/2 cups of cold water
and 3/4 of a cup of black lentils.
Bring up to a boil, then partially cover
with a pot lid and turn down to a medium
low temp. We're going to let this simmer
for about 15 minutes.
Next, we're going to sauté our shiakei
mushrooms. We're using shiakei because
they have three particularly healthy
compounds. Aergoionine, lentinine, and
aerotadin.
Bring your stainless steel pan up to a
really high heat for a few minutes so
that the pan becomes non-stick. I like
to take a teaspoon of water and splash
it onto the heated stainless steel pan.
If the water forms beads, that means
that your pan is officially non-stick
and ready for cooking.
Place the shiakei mushrooms in the
preheated pan with a teaspoon of avocado
oil or any type of high smoke point oil.
Cook for about 5 minutes, stirring
occasionally.
Once cooked, take your mushrooms off the
heat and set aside. Now, let's make our
dressing. Take a cup of cooked
chickpeas,
1 tbsp of nutritional yeast,
1 tbsp of olive oil,
one garlic clove,
a tablespoon of lemon juice,
4 tbsp of filtered water, and a handful
of chives.
Put everything in the blender and blend
for 30 seconds. High polyphenol olive
oil is the most powerful ingredient in
this dressing. It increases HDL or good
cholesterol and reduces several key
markers of cardiovascular disease. We
use blueprint olive oil as it has a very
high polyphenol count. Garlic has also
been shown to lower blood pressure and
help the immune system.
Once your lentils and vegetables have
been cooked, take everything off the
heat and set to cool.
Plate up by placing your lentils in a
shallow bowl. Next, take your roasted
vegetables, sauteed mushrooms, and a
handful or two of kale. Add our dressing
to the mixing bowl and give everything a
nice toss. Put a big helping of
vegetable mix on your lentils. Add in a
large pinch of hemp seeds and a wedge of
lemon. And that's it. You now have an
easy and nutritious meal that you can
make in less than 30 minutes. Enjoy.
